facts.text: General election to Mysore Legislative Assembly from Tarikere Constituency held in January 1952 with appellant, respondent No. 1 and eight others as nominated candidates.
Five nominated candidates withdrew; contest between remaining five including appellant and respondent No. 1.

Polling on 4th January 1952; counting on 26th January 1952. Respondent No. 1 secured 8,093 votes, appellant 8,059 votes, others 6,239, 1,644 and 1,142 votes. Returning Officer declared respondent No. 1 elected, published in Mysore Gazette on 11th February 1952.
Respondent No. 1 lodged return of election expenses; notice published in Mysore Gazette on 31st March 1952.

Appellant filed election petition dated 10th April 1952 by registered post to Election Commission, received 14th April 1952, challenging election on grounds of violation of election rules and corrupt practices by respondent No. 1 and agents; prayed declaration that respondent No. 1's election void and appellant duly elected.

Election Commission referred petition to Election Tribunal, Shimoga. On 25th October 1952, appellant applied for amendment under Order VI rule 17 CPC to modify prayer clause adding alternative prayer to declare entire election void; Tribunal allowed despite objection by respondent No. 1.

Tribunal framed 27 issues including: infringement of poll commencement time at Booth No. 1 Ajjampur (issue 1); hiring/procuring motor bus of Ahmed Jan (issue 5); assistance of Government servants (issue 6); false return of election expenses (issue 11); election procured by corrupt practices materially affecting result (issue 12); petitioner would have obtained majority but for corrupt/illegal practices (issue 14).
Tribunal by 2:1 majority found issues 1,5,6,11,12,14 in favour of petitioner; declared respondent No. 1's election void and petitioner duly elected on 15th January 1953.
Respondent No. 1 filed application under Article 226 before Mysore High Court on 5th February 1953 for writ of certiorari to quash Tribunal proceedings and order.
Mysore High Court Division Bench (Medappa C.J. and Balakrishnaiya J.) allowed petition, issued writ of certiorari quashing Tribunal order on 11th January 1954.
High Court granted certificate under Articles 132(1) and 133(1)(c); appellant appealed to Supreme Court.
Tribunal found polling at Booth No. 1 Ajjampur commenced 25 minutes late after 8 A.M., causing some voters to leave.
Tribunal found respondent No. 1 procured Ahmed Jan's service bus to convey about 60 voters in two trips to polling booths; Ahmed Jan acted as agent or with knowledge/connivance.
Tribunal found respondent No. 1 took assistance of Government servant Paramesshwarappa (Patel) who canvassed for him including at polling booth.
Tribunal found respondent No. 1's return of expenses false: omitted petrol for six additional cars (Rs. 1,250), hiring/loan charges for cars/vans tantamount to hiring, dinner/hotel expenses.

legal_issues.text: On what grounds could High Court under Article 226 grant certiorari to quash Election Tribunal's adjudication?

Whether grounds existed for certiorari: absence of jurisdiction (limitation extension, amendment), excess of jurisdiction (unpleaded issues, declaring petitioner elected without material), errors apparent on face of record (poll time, govt servant assistance, false expenses)?

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court misdirected on facts and law; Tribunal did not act without/excess jurisdiction or with error apparent on face; HC misread Tribunal findings.
Petition presented within time (14th April within 14 days of 31st March publication); amendment only modified prayer, no change in averments, original prayer granted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act s.81(2)(b), Rule 119

petitioner_arguments.text: Bus procurement pleaded via agent/with connivance; Tribunal finding on facts within pleadings; material for declaring petitioner elected as bus carried 60 voters, wiping out 34-vote margin.

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal without jurisdiction: extended limitation, allowed impermissible amendment beyond s.83(3); excess jurisdiction on unpleaded matters (Ahmed Jan agency/connivance), declared petitioner elected without finding/material on majority votes.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act s.83(3)

respondent_arguments.text: Errors apparent: poll delay finding speculative on votes; govt servant (Paramesshwarappa) mere canvassing not 'assistance taken'; false expenses on no evidence/speculation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act s.123(8), s.100(2)(c)

court_reasoning.text: Certiorari issues for jurisdictional error, excess, or error apparent on face; supervisory not appellate; does not reweigh evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principles from English law adopted under Constitution Arts.32,226.

court_reasoning.text: Petition timely (excludes publication date); amendment immaterial as original prayer granted, no averment change.
Bus issue within pleadings (agent/connivance alleged); 60 voters from bus wipes 34-vote margin with evidence.

Poll delay considered under s.100(2)(c) on probabilities; not basis for declaring petitioner elected. Govt servant assistance inferred from facts not error apparent. Expenses findings supported by evidence, not speculative.

holdings.text: High Court erred in issuing certiorari; no absence/excess of jurisdiction or error apparent.
Election Tribunal's findings on facts supported by evidence, within jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Election Commission, India v. Saka Venkata Subba Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Powers under Arts.32,226 for writs including certiorari.
Certiorari for judicial/quasi-judicial acts in excess of authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: King v. Nat. Bell Liquors Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Supervision over area of jurisdiction and observance of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appellate Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari corrects error of law on face, not appeal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Veerappa Pillai v. Ramon Raman Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.226 for grave jurisdictional errors, not appellate review.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court power to issue certiorari; certificate for appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Presentation of petition, amendment, void election for corrupt practices/irregularities, corrupt practice of govt servant assistance.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Election Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Time limit for petition after publication of expenses return.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Mysore High Court set aside; writ of certiorari issued by High Court vacated; Tribunal's order declaring respondent No. 1's election void and appellant duly elected restored implicitly.

key_quotes.text: The supervision of the superior Court exercised through writs of certiorari goes on two points... One is the area of inferior jurisdiction... the other is the observance of law in the course of its exercise.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Certiorari will not issue as the cloak of an appeal in disguise. It does not lie in order to bring up an order or decision for re-hearing... It exists to correct error of law when revealed on the face.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits certiorari to supervisory role, quoting Morris L.J.

key_quotes.text: However extensive the jurisdiction [Art.226] may be, it seems to us that it is not so wide... as to enable the High Court to convert itself into a Court of appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Restricts High Court from appellate review via writ.
